summary: An FBI Miami Division request to the Document Conversion Laboratory (DocLab) for scanning and automation assistance regarding telephone records related to the obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez. The document reveals Rodriguez, former house manager for Jeffrey Epstein, attempted to sell an address book believed to contain contact information for additional, previously unknown underage victims of Epstein.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.role: Former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein; subject of obstruction of justice case
persons.context: The subject of the FBI's obstruction of justice investigation. He attempted to sell an address book containing names and numbers of potential underage victims of Epstein rather than turn it over to authorities.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Subject of a child prostitution case
persons.context: Identified as the individual whose former house manager, Alfredo Rodriguez, possessed an address book believed to contain contact information for Epstein's additional underage victims.

connections.description: Rodriguez was the former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein.
Rodriguez possessed an address book believed to contain information on Epstein's underage victims and attempted to sell it, obstructing justice in Epstein's case.

events.title: FBI opens obstruction case against Rodriguez
events.description: Miami Division opened an obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez.

events.title: FBI requests scanning of telephone records
events.description: FBI Miami submits a request to the DocLab to scan and automate telephone records obtained from an address book in the Rodriguez obstruction case.

locations: Winchester, Virginia 22602 (DocLab - Telephone Application Audit Processing Team, 170 Marcel Drive)
keyFacts: Alfredo Rodriguez, Jeffrey Epstein's former house manager and butler, was the subject of an FBI obstruction of justice case opened in October 2009.
Rodriguez came into possession of an address book containing names and telephone numbers believed to belong to additional, previously unknown underage victims of Jeffrey Epstein.
Rodriguez attempted to sell the address book to an Undercover Employee (UCE) instead of turning it over to law enforcement or attorneys in response to federal subpoenas.
The FBI was processing telephone records obtained from this address book, believed to belong to Epstein, his associates, or potential underage victims.
The document is an internal FBI request for technical assistance (scanning and data formatting) to incorporate these records into the Bureau's investigative database (TA).
